text: It was an accident of history that this Slack was named "Future of Programming" and my podcast was named "Future of Coding", and that I now run these two things with ever-so-slightly different names. Anyone <!here> opposed to me renaming this Slack to "Future of Coding" and changing the url to <http://futureofcoding.slack.com|futureofcoding.slack.com>? All old messages will be saved and the old URL will automatically redirect to the new one (until somebody else registers the old name)

text: I started the <#CCL5VVBAN|share-your-work> channel because I didn't want <#C5T9GPWFL|thinking-together> to devolve into self-promotion, but now I think it's a bit of an artificial distinction. I'm thinking of discontinuing the <#CCL5VVBAN|share-your-work> channel in favor of what HN does: simply put "Show FoC:" or or "Feedback Request:" something like that when you want to share something you made yourself. Thoughts?

text:
This meta channel actually fits dictionary meaning for meta:

<https://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=meta>

It’s the coding term that it doesn’t directly fit.

attachments.title: Urban Dictionary: meta
attachments.text: 1. Meta means about the thing itself. It's seeing the thing from a higher perspective instead of from within the thing, like being self-aware. 2. A term used in mmo meaning the Most Effective Tactic Available. It's basically what works in a game regardless of what you wish would work.

elements.text: This meta channel actually fits dictionary meaning for meta:
It’s the coding term that it doesn’t directly fit.

text:
Here's what I wrote on that in the README:

> This community was started by Irvin Hwang as a Google Group in mid-2017 for organizing NYC meetups, but was quickly turned into a Slack and taken over by Steve Krouse when Irvin got busy with his job.
> .
>The Slack is loosely connected to the Future of Coding podcast -- people hear about it there and sometimes discuss episodes -- but it’s only one of many common touch points for the community, including Bret Victor, Douglas Engelbart, Alan Kay, Fred Brooks, HCI, HARC, Eve...

elements.text: Here's what I wrote on that in the README:

This community was started by Irvin Hwang as a Google Group in mid-2017 for organizing NYC meetups, but was quickly turned into a Slack and taken over by Steve Krouse when Irvin got busy with his job.
.
The Slack is loosely connected to the Future of Coding podcast -- people hear about it there and sometimes discuss episodes -- but it’s only one of many common touch points for the community, including Bret Victor, Douglas Engelbart, Alan Kay, Fred Brooks, HCI, HARC, Eve...

text:
#collaboration suggests that it’s a channel for people to discuss collaborative projects. That term has been used that way in other communities, at least.

I think there’s an easy distinction between <#CEXED56UR|administrivia> as it is now and some hypothetical #metaprogramming. Also, the channel description takes away any uncertainty.

text: I like <#CCL5VVBAN|share-your-work> because it reduces the pressure on <#C5T9GPWFL|thinking-together>. For instance, if there’s an active conversation or a recent post in <#C5T9GPWFL|thinking-together>, I’m going to feel extra spammy if I post something like “forget that, look at my thing gang!”. By having a separate channel, <#C5T9GPWFL|thinking-together> is that much less likely to become chaotic.

text:
Several people here said that they don't *like* Slack and several others mentioned that they don't *know* Slack — maybe it's important to make that distinction?
If you don't _know_ Slack: You can subscribe to any thread by clicking the three dots and selecting "Follow Thread" and will then receive notifications (depending on your notification settings) and new messages will also show up in the "New Threads" channel. When you reply in a thread, you will automatically be subscribed to it (and it's as easy to unsubscribe; same process). Works the same on mobile, you get into a thread or create one by tapping a message. This is how I try to deal with volume. Tools > Process.

When you reply in a thread, you will automatically be subscribed to it (and it's as easy to unsubscribe; same process). Works the same on mobile, you get into a thread or create one by tapping a message. This is how I try to deal with volume. Tools > Process.
